q1.value: Grassroot autonomy 4: Is autonomy perceived to be linked to morality?

q2.value: Elli Zey, Matthias Sehlbrede, Hasti Mohammai Rouchi, Sabine Windmann

q3.value: The present study is the fourth of a study series aiming at a bottom-up approach defining autonomy. In this study we want to examine whether morality and unusualness are linked to the perceived autonomy reflected in the items generated by laypersons in previous studies (grassroot autonomy study 1-3: https://osf.io/yqwr8/).

q4.value:
We expect autonomy item ratings from study 3 to correlate significantly positive with morality ratings in this study. 
Additionally, we expect high-autonomy items to be rated significantly higher in unusualness compared to low-autonomy items.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Participants are asked to fill out an online survey, in which they will be presented 40 autonomy items, generated in study 2.2 (https://osf.io/r8xeh/), that have been ranked in their degree of autonomy. The subjects are asked to rate the degree of morality for each autonomy-item on a five-point Likert-scale. 
Additionally, the subjects will be presented 10 autonomy-items that in previous studies have been found to have the 5 highest and 5 lowest ratings in autonomy. The task is to rate these items in unusualness on a five-point Likert-scale.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The subjects will be recruited by a psychology bachelor student through peers and acquaintances. Additionally, the survey will be shared via social media and by handouts. The participants cannot be paid for their participation, although psychology undergraduate students have the opportunity to collect credits for experimental participation.

q13.value: For this study the g*power analysis calculated a required sample size of N=122. We therefore aim for N=122 participants. If we cannot fulfill this due to time and resource pressures (Bachelor thesis is bound to time limit), we will stop collecting data after 30 days.

q14.value: We plan to conduct bivariate correlations between autonomy ratings of study 2.2 and the morality ratings obtained in this study. To estimate the required sample size with the power analysis software g*power, we performed a priori analyses (one-tailed). For a small effect rho=.3 and a power of .95, we need a sample size of N=111. Additionally, we plan to conduct a dependent t-Test to analyze the difference between high and low autonomy on unusualness. A priori power analyses (one-tailed) yielded a required sample size of N=122 to find an effect of Cohens d=.3 with a power of .95.

q15.value: According to our power analyses we aim to conduct a sample size of N=122; if this is not possible within 30 days of data collection, we will stop on day 30.

question.value: We collect morality ratings of all 40 autonomy items on a 5-point Likert-scale (1 = ‘not at all moral’, 5 = ‘completely moral’). We will calculate a morality score over the means of these ratings. In total we will randomly place three attention checks in the above rating items. Furthermore, we will ask for ratings in unusualness on a 5-point Likert-scale (1 = ‘not at all unusual’, 5 = ‘completely unusual’) for the 5 highest and lowest rated autonomy items from grassroot autonomy 2.2. For demographics we will assess education, gender and age.

For analyzing the link between autonomy and morality, we will calculate Pearson correlation (if normal distribution is are violated, we will use non-parametric Spearman’s Rho) between autonomy and morality. To compare the high and low autonomy items in regard to the unusualness rating, we will calculate a dependent t-Test and report the effect size Cohens d.

q21.value: We will use standard p=.05 criterion for significance and report exact p-values and effect sizes.

q22.value: Participants who fail on one or more attention check items will be excluded from the analysis. Additionally, speeders (faster than 0.25 * median time) will be excluded.

q23.value: Only participants who finished all items on morality as well as all items on unusalness will be included in the analysis.

attributes.title: Protocol: Qingzao Jiufei Decoction for Prevention and Treatment of Radiation-induced Lung Injury (RILI): A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis
attributes.description: Radiation-induced lung injury (RILI) is one of the most common serious complications after radiotherapy. Radiation pneumonitis is the main manifestation in the early stage and pulmonary fibrosis in the later stage. At present, there is no effective way to prevent or treat radiation-induced lung injury, which has become the limiting factor of radiation dose for chest tumor. The main clinical treatment is oxygen inhalation, bed rest, the use of bronchodilators, antibiotics and glucocorticoids symptomatic treatment, but the overall effect is not good, Chinese medicine in the treatment of radiation lung injury has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on Qingzao Jiufei Decoction for the RILI. Therefore, research on it is needed.

q1.value: Qingzao Jiufei Decoction for Prevention and Treatment of Radiation-induced Lung Injury (RILI): Protocol for A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis

q2.value: Haiyan Yu, Qinwei Fu, Zongming Yu, Meiying Yue, Wei Xie, Qinxiu Zhang, Fengming You

q3.value: Radiation-induced lung injury (RILI) is one of the most common serious complications after radiotherapy. Radiation pneumonitis is the main manifestation in the early stage and pulmonary fibrosis in the later stage. At present, there is no effective way to prevent or treat radiation-induced lung injury, which has become the limiting factor of radiation dose for chest tumor. The main clinical treatment is oxygen inhalation, bed rest, the use of bronchodilators, antibiotics and glucocorticoids symptomatic treatment, but the overall effect is not good, Chinese medicine in the treatment of radiation lung injury has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on Qingzao Jiufei Decoction for the RILI. Therefore, research on it is needed.

q4.value:
1. Qingzao Jiufei decoction is effective for prevention and treatment of patients with radiation-induced pulmonary injury (RILI).
2. How does the efficacy of Qingzao Jiufei decoction compare to that with Western medicine therapies alone, other TCM therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
3. There are some moderating variables associated with prevention and treatment efficacy in studies of Qingzao Jiufei decoction for patients with the radiation-induced pulmonary injury (RILI).

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

q7.value:
Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.
Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.

The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

question.value:
1. Anticipated start date: 23/02/2020;

2. Anticipated completion date: 13/06/2020;

3.Review question: ①. Is the Qingzao Jiufei decoction effective for prevention and treatment of patients with radiation-induced pulmonary injury (RILI)? 
                ②. How does the efficacy of the Qingzao Jiufei decoction compare to that with other TCM therapies alone, Western medicine therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions? 
                ③. What moderating variables are associated with treatment efficacy in studies of the Qingzao Jiufei decoction for patients with the NCP? 

4. Searches: English databases including PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Library and Chinese databases including CNKI, Wanfang, VIP databases will be searched. The research will start following the PRISMA protocol.
The terms used in the search will follow the rules of the Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) and the question that guided the search was based on the PICOS strategy (participants, interventions, comparison, results and studies). search strategy information can be found in the attached PDF document (link provided below).
One month will be allocated for data collection and one month for article analysis.
Retrieval time is from the inception dates of the databases to 17 Mar, 2020.
We also considered the alternative terms and spellings for keywords.
In addition, the references of initially included literature were traced back to achieve a comprehensive search. English and Chinese language were included.

5. Condition or domain being studied: Radiation-induced lung injury (RILI) is one of the most common serious complications after radiotherapy. Radiation pneumonitis is the main manifestation in the early stage and pulmonary fibrosis in the later stage. At present, there is no effective way to prevent or treat radiation-induced lung injury, which has become the limiting factor of radiation dose for chest tumor. The main clinical treatment is oxygen inhalation, bed rest, the use of bronchodilators, antibiotics and glucocorticoids symptomatic treatment, but the overall effect is not good, Chinese medicine in the treatment of radiation lung injury has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on Qingzao Jiufei Decoction for the RILI. Therefore, research on it is needed.

6.Participants/population: Patients with chest tumor and receiving radiotherapy, regardless of gender, etiology, ethnic group, severity, diagnosed with specific criteria are eligible for inclusion.

7. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of the Qingzao Jiufei decoction, including dosage forms of pieces of traditional Chinese medicine, boil-free granule of Traditional Chinese medicine, Chinese patent drug and other available forms.

8. Comparator(s)/control: Including TCM therapies alone, Western medicine therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included.

9. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

10. Main outcome(s): ①Incidence of radiation pneumonitis;
                   ②Incidence of radiation-induced pulmonary fibrosis；
                   ③Karndfsky quality of life score;
                   ④Total effective rate;

11. Additional outcome(s): ① Improvement of solid tumor in the near future;
                       ②Patient survival time;

12. Data extraction (selection and coding): Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.

13.Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.
The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

14. Strategy for data synthesis: Statistical analyses will be performed using RevMan 5.3 software (The Cochrane Collaboration).
- Pooled risk ratio (RR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) of dichotomous outcomes will be used to report effect estimate.
- Continuous data will be presented as mean difference (MD) with 95% CI. If different measurement scales are used, standardized mean difference (SMD) will be performed to analyze continuous data.
If required data are not reported, we will try to obtain data from corresponding author.
Heterogeneity will be assessed using both the χ² test and the I² statistic, and we will consider an I² value greater than 50% indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
- For I²<50%, a fixed-effect model is used.
- For I² >=50%, a random-effect model is applied.
If data permit, we plan to exclude some trials that contribuite most to the heterogeneity to see whether the result change or not.
We will also use a summary of findings table to present the main findings using GRADEpro software (The Cochrane Collaboration). Funnel plots will be generated to detect publication bias if more than 10 trials are identified to report the same outcomes. If appropriate, we will use cumulative meta-analyses. Results of meta-analyses will be visualized by forest plots. In addition, we will conduct trial sequential analysis to evaluate the meta-analyses for primary outcomes, which can reveal the required information size and potentially false results in a meta-analysis. Intention-to-treat analysis will be applied for primary outcome, if missing data from the original trials are available.

15. Analysis of subgroups or subsets: If data permitted, we plan to conduct subgroup analyses for different groups, including:
Different age of patients
Different severity of disease
Different regimen applied
Different treat time
Different acupoints selected
Combined with other interventions or not.

16. Type and method of review: intervention; Meta-analysis; Prevention; Systematic review.

17. Health area of the review: Complementary therapies; Cnacer; Public health; Respiratory disorders; 

18. Languages of the review: English and Chinese;

19. Dissemination plans: In addition to producing a report, a paper will be submitted to a journal in this field.

20. Keywords: Chinese herbal medicine; Prevention; Treatment; Radiation-induced Lung Injury (RILI).

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

2. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of the Qingzao Jiufei decoction, including dosage forms of pieces of traditional Chinese medicine, boil-free granule of Traditional Chinese medicine, Chinese patent drug and other available forms.

3. Comparator(s)/control: Including TCM therapies alone, Western medicine therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included.

4. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

At present, there is no effective way to prevent or treat radiation-induced lung injury, which has become the limiting factor of radiation dose for chest tumor. The main clinical treatment is oxygen inhalation, bed rest, the use of bronchodilators, antibiotics and glucocorticoids symptomatic treatment, but the overall effect is not good, Chinese medicine in the treatment of radiation lung injury has done a lot of research, the effect is significant. There are no SR or protocol on Qingzao Jiufei Decoction for the RILI. Therefore, research on it is needed.

6.Participants/population: Patients with chest tumor and receiving radiotherapy, regardless of gender, etiology, ethnic group, severity, diagnosed with specific criteria are eligible for inclusion.

7. Intervention(s), exposure(s): Treatment of the Qingzao Jiufei decoction, including dosage forms of pieces of traditional Chinese medicine, boil-free granule of Traditional Chinese medicine, Chinese patent drug and other available forms.

8. Comparator(s)/control: Including TCM therapies alone, Western medicine therapies alone, blank control, placebo control and other interventions. Interventions in the experimental group were not included.

9. Types of study to be included: We will include randomised controlled trials (RCTs), published and unpublished, in English and Chinese.

10. Main outcome(s): ①Incidence of radiation pneumonitis;
                   ②Incidence of radiation-induced pulmonary fibrosis；
                   ③Karndfsky quality of life score;
                   ④Total effective rate;

11. Additional outcome(s): ① Improvement of solid tumor in the near future;
                       ②Patient survival time;

12. Data extraction (selection and coding): Three reviewers searched the online databases listed above and recorded the titles and abstracts of all the articles.
Three evaluators assessed the eligibility of these articles and made decisions on every research (inclusion or exclusion) independently. If they did not reach the same decision, the concerned articles were discussed with a fourth reviewer.
Three reviewers extracted data independently from each study.
Differences regarding the extracted data were resolved after discussion with a fourth reviewer.

13.Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Three authors of our review team will independently assess the methodological quality of included trials, and consensus will be reached by discussion with a third party in case of discrepancy.
The methodological quality of RCTs will be assessed according to the risk of bias tool described in the Cochrane Handbook for Systematic Reviews of Interventions [Higgins JPT 2009]. Six elements will be assessed: random sequence generation, allocation concealment, blinding of outcome assessors, incomplete outcome data, free of selective reporting, and other bias. Disagreements will be resolved by discussion with a third party.

14. Strategy for data synthesis: Statistical analyses will be performed using RevMan 5.3 software (The Cochrane Collaboration).
- Pooled risk ratio (RR) with 95% confidence interval (CI) of dichotomous outcomes will be used to report effect estimate.
- Continuous data will be presented as mean difference (MD) with 95% CI. If different measurement scales are used, standardized mean difference (SMD) will be performed to analyze continuous data.
If required data are not reported, we will try to obtain data from corresponding author.
Heterogeneity will be assessed using both the χ² test and the I² statistic, and we will consider an I² value greater than 50% indicative of substantial heterogeneity.
- For I²<50%, a fixed-effect model is used.
- For I² >=50%, a random-effect model is applied.
If data permit, we plan to exclude some trials that contribuite most to the heterogeneity to see whether the result change or not.
We will also use a summary of findings table to present the main findings using GRADEpro software (The Cochrane Collaboration). Funnel plots will be generated to detect publication bias if more than 10 trials are identified to report the same outcomes. If appropriate, we will use cumulative meta-analyses. Results of meta-analyses will be visualized by forest plots. In addition, we will conduct trial sequential analysis to evaluate the meta-analyses for primary outcomes, which can reveal the required information size and potentially false results in a meta-analysis. Intention-to-treat analysis will be applied for primary outcome, if missing data from the original trials are available.

15. Analysis of subgroups or subsets: If data permitted, we plan to conduct subgroup analyses for different groups, including:
Different age of patients
Different severity of disease
Different regimen applied
Different treat time
Different acupoints selected
Combined with other interventions or not.

16. Type and method of review: intervention; Meta-analysis; Prevention; Systematic review.

17. Health area of the review: Complementary therapies; Cnacer; Public health; Respiratory disorders; 

18. Languages of the review: English and Chinese;

19. Dissemination plans: In addition to producing a report, a paper will be submitted to a journal in this field.

20. Keywords: Chinese herbal medicine; Prevention; Treatment; Radiation-induced Lung Injury (RILI).

attributes.title: Entrenched versus Shallow Norms in Foreign Policy: Evidence on the Chemical and Nuclear Weapons Taboos

q1.value: Entrenched versus Shallow Norms in Foreign Policy: Evidence on the Chemical and Nuclear Weapons Taboos

q2.value: Christopher W. Blair | Jonathan A. Chu | Joshua A. Schwartz

q5.value: Generous support for this research is provided by the Christopher H. Browne Center for International Politics at the University of Pennsylvania.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Prominent international relations scholars argue that the use of certain weapons – most notably weapons of mass destruction (WMD) like chemical and nuclear weapons — are taboo (Price 1995; 1997; Tannenwald 1999, 2008). However, recent research on the nuclear taboo (Press, Sagan, and Valentino 2013; Sagan and Valentino 2017; Pauly 2018), combined with rampant chemical weapons use in Syria and President Trump’s nuclear saber-rattling against North Korea, calls into question the strength of the nuclear and chemical “taboos.” We argue that there may be two types of norm-holders: sincere norm-holders that publicly and privately support a norm, and shallow norm-holders that publicly support a norm in order to avoid social sanction, but privately oppose it. Given that the two variants of this norm are observationally equivalent in traditional surveys, existing literature may overestimate the extent to which the public has internalized certain norms. In order to test this argument, we utilize a list experiment design, which is a technique used to estimate people’s opinions about chemical and nuclear weapons use.

q16.value: We posit the following hypotheses. First, individuals are more likely to support nuclear/chemical weapons use when asked indirectly than directly. Second, peer and elite cues in support of nuclear/chemical weapons use will reduce the gap in support between direct and indirect question formats. We use univariate and multivariate regression to estimate support for nuclear/chemical weapons in direct question and list experimental formats.

q17.value: To test our theory we propose a combined list-direct question survey experimental design (Blair and Imai 2012; Aronow, Coppock, Crawford, and Green 2015; Eady 2017). Specifically, we conduct two list experiments paralleling two direct questions. In the first list-direct question pair we investigate the nuclear weapons taboo (Study A). In the second pair we investigate the chemical weapons taboo (Study B).

q23.value: We are awaiting IRB approval. Our proposal is currently under IRB review

registration_responses.q2: Christopher W. Blair | Jonathan A. Chu | Joshua A. Schwartz
registration_responses.q5: Generous support for this research is provided by the Christopher H. Browne Center for International Politics at the University of Pennsylvania.

attributes.title: Common neural markers of obsessive-compulsive disorder, substance use disorder, and  gaming disorder – an activation likelihood meta-analysis of functional imaging studies

q1.value: Common neural markers of obsessive-compulsive disorder, substance use disorder, and  gaming disorder – an activation likelihood meta-analysis of functional imaging studies

q2.value: Benjamin Becker, Benjamin Klugah-Brown, Bharat Biswal

q3.value: Compulsivity represents an underlying behavioral dysregulation across obsessive-compulsive disorder, substance use disorders, and gaming disorder. The present meta-analysis aims at determining common neural alterations in these disorders by capitalizing on previous fMRI studies conducted in individuals with obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), chronic substance use (SUD) and (internet) gaming disorder (IGD).

q4.value: Based on the previous literature we hypothesize shared alterations in the frontal and striatal regions between these disorders.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: ALE Meta-analysis including case control studies on human subjects with SUD, IGD, and OCD

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value:
For the determination of the meta-analytic SUD network data from our previous meta-analysis on reward and cognitive fMRI paradigms in SUD, individuals will be used (Klugha-Brown et al., doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.02.19.956755). Briefly, our previous meta-analysis included 99 fMRI studies on reward and cognitive processes in individuals with excessive cocaine, cannabis, alcohol, and nicotine use. Findings demonstrated robust alterations across SUD individuals in striatal and frontal regions. Based on these results we now aim at conducting identical meta-analysis encompassing previous studies in OCD and IGD individuals to determine common neural markers between these disorders. Previous meta-analyses either focused on IGD individuals (Zheng et al., 2019; doi: 10.1016/j.pnpbp.2019.109656, or Yao et al., 2017; doi: 10.1016/j.neubiorev.2017.10.029) or OCD individuals (e.g.Pico-Perez et al., 2020; doi: 10.1016/j.neubiorev.2020.01.033). Based on previous meta-analyses and overarching disorder models of compulsivity we consider the number of original studies suitable for a cross-diagnostic analysis. 
Prior to the publication of the pre-registration, we screened recent meta-analysis and original studies to explore whether the number of studies allows a meta-analytic approach. The data for the SUD meta-analysis has been collected and analyzed in our previous ALE meta-analysis (Klugah-Brown et al., doi: https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.02.19.956755, a preprint of the corresponding manuscript has been archived on the biorxiv preprint repository).

question.value: A literature search according to inclusion and exclusion criteria will be conducted: we will adhere to Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) (Moher et al 2009) and principles of conduction coordinate-based meta-analysis (Müller et al 2018). We will primarily conduct a literature search on tasks-based fMRI studies of SUD, IGD, and OCD using relevant databases as well as search references in related reviews. The literature will be entirely based on whole-brain analysis and task paradigm from SUD, OCD and IGD studies published between January 1st, 2000 to January 31st, 2020 using the following search terms, “functional magnetic resonance imaging” OR “fMRI” AND “substance use disorder” OR “Obsessive-compulsive disorder” OR “internet gaming disorder” on the following four databases: PubMed, Web of science, Neurosynth and Scopus. We will ensure that all articles include control subjects and report results of comparisons of the disorder group with the healthy control groups. The exclusion criteria will be as follows: 1. Articles reporting only region-of-interest (ROI) results (if the study additionally reported whole-brain corrected findings these will be included), 2. Articles with poly-drug users and high comorbidities with psychiatric or somatic disorders (e.g. schizophrenia or HIV), 3. Articles focusing on parental exposure, and 4. Articles reporting results from the exact same dataset as previous studies.

q13.value: The sample size for our previous SUD meta-analysis is n = 99. Final sample size for the SUD and IGD analyses will be determined during screening of literature and applying the inclusion/exclusion criteria

q14.value: Based on previous meta-analysis and current recommendations for meta-analysis in fMRI studies (Müller et al., 2018)  we expect a sufficient number of IGD and SUD studies to warrant sufficient power for the new meta-analysis.

q15.value: No stopping rule given that existing data will be used

question.value: Outcome variables will be coordinates of brain regions (clusters) showing significant differences between the disorder groups and controls

We will observe the consistency in reported brain regions showing differences in activation between the three groups of disorder relative to the respective control groups employing the coordinate-based meta-analytic approach for fMRI studies: 
We will perform the coordinate-based analysis using the GingerALE 3.0.2 (Eickhoff, Bzdok, Laird, Kurth, & Fox, 2012; Eickhoff et al., 2011, 2009), by first manually extracting coordinates including the number of subjects in each study, we will also make sure all articles reported their stereoscope coordinates in either Talairach or MNI (Montreal Neurological Institute) space. Basically, ALE tries to find the strongest agreement between the experiments. This is achieved by computing the union between the generated maps while taking into account the disparities between true activation and noise. Also, to address the spatial uncertainty linked to the foci, the three-dimensional Gaussian probability distribution is applied to centers of the coordinates and images derived from the foci for all experiments obtained as modeled activation (MA). The ALE uses the convergence of whole-brain coordinates from experiments under nonrandom spatial distribution to create clusters formed by equal probabilities of voxels. Finally, ALE is outputted as clusters where the convergence is located. Cluster-level Family-wise error (cluster-FWE) (Eickhoff et al., 2016) correction will be applied to the ALE results to account for multiple comparisons. The cluster-FWE thresholding is the most appropriate balance between sensitivity and specificity. The ALE maps will initially be thresholded using the uncorrected cluster forming p <0.001 and cluster-level threshold p<0.05. The p-value accounts for the proportion of the random spatial relation between the various experiments under the null distribution. We will analyze the difference and overlaps (conjunction) among the three groups, by firstly computing their ALE separately, then creating a pooled coordinate between any two groups (yielding 6 permutations). At each computation of voxel, significant clusters will be estimated by applying 5000 (Yeung et al. 2017, Englemann et al., 2012; Laird et al., 2010) Monte-Carlo simulation Values representing voxel probabilities.

Activation Likelihood Estimation meta-analyses using the cluster-level FWE, p< 0.05 and cluster formation, p<0.001 to correct for multiple comparisons will be applied. From the whole-brain data collected, we will conduct statistical analysis following the cluster-FWE procedure recommended by (Eickhoff et al., 2016) and the number of permutations as reported in  (Yeung et al. 2017, Englemann et al., 2012; Laird et al., 2010). We will also conduct exploratory analysis involving the extraction of the probability of functional changes per-voxel, and the contributions from each experiment task as well as correlation analysis between confounding parameters in each study.  The GingerALE software has an inbuilt Cluster-FWE algorithm (Eickhoff, S. B., Bzdok, D., Laird, A. R., Kurth, F., & Fox, P. T., 2012).  We will analyze the differences in convergent activation and locations where significant alterations are present between groups. Firstly, for the contrast analysis, we will use the subtraction method to uncover significant clusters characterizing each experiment. Using the corrected maps of the individual ALEs voxel differences will be computed to determine significant activation within each study. Null distributions will then be generated from the ALE scores using random permutation of all experiments, then the ALE score of the equal-sized group similar to the individual computed maps will be randomly permuted for all the voxels in the represented brain as implemented in the software. Secondly, as we aim to uncover similarities among the three groups by identifying the significant effect that is likely to occur between two individual studies, we will compute the conjunctions between two studies each using the same thresholding as in the subtraction analysis FEW-corrected p<0.05 and cluster formation p< 0.001. The subtraction and conjunction procedure is given in the manual of the GingerALE software 3.0.2 “Contrast analysis compares and contrasts two ALEdatasets. A conjunction image shows the similarity between the datasets. The conjunction is created using the voxel‐wise minimum value of the input ALE images. Two ALE contrast images are created by directly subtracting one input image from the other. This ALE subtraction image does not take into account differences between the studies. To correct for study sizes (Eickhoff et al., 2011), GingerALE creates simulated data by pooling the foci datasets and randomly dividing them into two now groupings of the same size as the original data sets. An ALE image is created for each new data set, then subtracted from the other and compared to the true data. After many permutations, we have a voxel‐wise P-value image showing where the true data’s values sit on the distribution of values in that voxel. In certain cases, a very small or even negative value could be significantly high on the distribution. To simplify interpretation of ALE contrast images, they are converted to Z scores to show their significance instead of a direct ALE subtraction. Cluster analysis of contrast images uses Z score values in the image statistics and maxima…The contrast analysis is restricted to voxels that were significant in at least one of the three input images.” Finally, for the exploratory analysis, we will group all experiments based on the Research Domain Criteria fremawork (RDoC) (Insel et al, 2010), “The RDoC framework is the best approximation to a criterion approach to the classification of the array of activation tasks used in the primary studies and enables a principled interpretation of results in terms of dysfunction in clearly defined cognitive processes” and based on the coding method reported in (Janiri et al 2020). We will follow the RDoC domain approach which consists of five RDoC domains; cognitive systems, positive valence systems, negative valence systems, cross-domain systems, and social processing. For each of the main effects and conjunction, the probability of functional changes will be extracted per-voxel, the contributions from each experiment task coded by the RDoC will be used to conduct the statistical test for independence. This analysis aims at resolving biases as well as the heterogeneous nature of the various experiments included in the meta-analysis. Further, the analysis will be conducted using the confounding parameters such as the severity of the disorder in each study

q20.value: Coordinates from the original studies will be converted to MNI standard space for statistical comparison. Coordinates reported in Talairach space will be converted to the MNI space using GingerALE software. Results will be reported in MNI space.

q21.value: Clusters showing significant difference among the three groups and between pairs of groups will be reported in MNI space coordinate space (x, y, and z) as well as their cluster size, peak coordinates from voxels, labels of brain regions, number of experiments contributing to the clusters and the RDoC domain associated with the experiment at each cluster. Further details see also analysis plan section.

q22.value: The exclusion criteria for the data from original studies will be as follows: 1. Articles reporting only region-of-interest (ROI) results (if the study additionally reported whole-brain corrected findings these will be included), 2. Articles with poly-drug users and high comorbidities with psychiatric or somatic disorders (e.g. schizophrenia or HIV), 3. Articles focusing on parental exposure, and 4. Articles reporting results from the exact same dataset as previous studies.

Firstly, for the contrast analysis, we will use the subtraction method to uncover significant clusters characterizing each experiment. Using the corrected maps of the individual ALEs voxel differences will be computed to determine significant activation within each study. Null distributions will then be generated from the ALE scores using random permutation of all experiments, then the ALE score of the equal-sized group similar to the individual computed maps will be randomly permuted for all the voxels in the represented brain as implemented in the software. Secondly, as we aim to uncover similarities among the three groups by identifying the significant effect that is likely to occur between two individual studies, we will compute the conjunctions between two studies each using the same thresholding as in the subtraction analysis FEW-corrected p<0.05 and cluster formation p< 0.001. The subtraction and conjunction procedure is given in the manual of the GingerALE software 3.0.2 “Contrast analysis compares and contrasts two ALEdatasets. A conjunction image shows the similarity between the datasets. The conjunction is created using the voxel‐wise minimum value of the input ALE images. Two ALE contrast images are created by directly subtracting one input image from the other. This ALE subtraction image does not take into account differences between the studies. To correct for study sizes (Eickhoff et al., 2011), GingerALE creates simulated data by pooling the foci datasets and randomly dividing them into two now groupings of the same size as the original data sets. An ALE image is created for each new data set, then subtracted from the other and compared to the true data. After many permutations, we have a voxel‐wise P-value image showing where the true data’s values sit on the distribution of values in that voxel. In certain cases, a very small or even negative value could be significantly high on the distribution. To simplify interpretation of ALE contrast images, they are converted to Z scores to show their significance instead of a direct ALE subtraction. Cluster analysis of contrast images uses Z score values in the image statistics and maxima…The contrast analysis is restricted to voxels that were significant in at least one of the three input images.” Finally, for the exploratory analysis, we will group all experiments based on the Research Domain Criteria fremawork (RDoC) (Insel et al, 2010), “The RDoC framework is the best approximation to a criterion approach to the classification of the array of activation tasks used in the primary studies and enables a principled interpretation of results in terms of dysfunction in clearly defined cognitive processes” and based on the coding method reported in (Janiri et al 2020). We will follow the RDoC domain approach which consists of five RDoC domains; cognitive systems, positive valence systems, negative valence systems, cross-domain systems, and social processing. For each of the main effects and conjunction, the probability of functional changes will be extracted per-voxel, the contributions from each experiment task coded by the RDoC will be used to conduct the statistical test for independence. This analysis aims at resolving biases as well as the heterogeneous nature of the various experiments included in the meta-analysis. Further, the analysis will be conducted using the confounding parameters such as the severity of the disorder in each study
